channel.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
channel.description: Now, I love me a big lead melody and a bit of a lead solo. So, ‚Ä¶   Post SC/YT links to one or two of your tracks with the strongest lead melody ‚Äì or solo, if you have any. Any genre.

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: Db909
item.description:
Absolutely. My goal has always been to create ‚Äúinstrumental‚Äù tracks that sort of stand on their own as songs due to the melodies that hopefully people are able to follow and hum along to. The idea is to get people singing the sounds ‚Äúbloop da be doo, bum bum bum‚Äù, etc lol

Read full topic
item.source: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Db909:

Really enjoy your tracks as well, strong melodies for sure.

Thanks. I‚Äôm trying not to simply use my own stuff as examples of what I‚Äôm getting at.

My own melodies might not be the most fantastic (though I think they‚Äôre pretty hot [ ] and still find them quite hooky, even though I wrote 'em), but as you say, there‚Äôs little question that I use melodies quite prominently, in most of my stuff.

To put it in really basic terms, I appreciate melodies that make me wanna sing/whistle/hum along ‚Äì or that I‚Äôll be whistling for the next couple of days.

Read full topic

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: Db909
item.description:
Thank you! Glad you enjoyed. I would‚Äôve loved to do a big proper production of walkie Talkie but it just so happened to be born within the very limited iKaossilator app and for me there comes a point where a piece just is what it is, even if you try to make it better it‚Äôs just not the same song anymore. Really enjoy your tracks as well, strong melodies for sure.

Read full topic
item.source: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Wouldn‚Äôt say that the lead melody in Walkie Talkie is big and exuberant, but I do think the track is the best example yet of what I‚Äôm getting at.

I think it helps that the track is kinda structured like a song, with clear sections, each with their own key melody. You return to some like a chorus and that makes the track move along nicely.

Because of that '70s funky bass sound (love it), and because melody was more of a thing, I couldn‚Äôt help but hope there was going to be a breakdown, with a funky af bass solo, ahead of the last ‚Äòchorus‚Äô (the bit that first appears at 1:20).

(Liked and Reposted.)

 

I can program some decent ones in a piano roll but that‚Äôs a compromise

I understand what you‚Äôre saying here.
I think I‚Äôve become accustomed to working effectively in Auxy, either devising melodies outside and quickly sequencing them, or exploring directly in Auxy.

Either way, I think my solos and leads come off quite well ‚Äì which is to say that I think it‚Äôs possible to sequence convincing melodies in Auxy. (Given my playing ability isn‚Äôt hot, I don‚Äôt see Auxy sequencing as a limitation.)

 

‚Ä¶ (click for more details)

Read full topic

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: Db909
item.description:
Well my melodies are a defining characteristic and all but most of my best ones don‚Äôt come from Auxy as I do my best melody work when I am able to improvise live and then tweak a bit. I can program some decent ones in a piano roll but that‚Äôs a compromise. Check out ‚Äúwalkie Talkie‚Äù on my SoundCloud for some big exuberant melodies

Read full topic
item.source: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
could you elaborate on what you meant by texturing in your original reply

Good use of under-melodies and counter-melodies.
Additionally, the main melody felt like it was serving more as a rhythmic texture, rather than a free-roaming lead melody. Add to that, the Corner > organ-y sound made the most prominent melody a little more recessive/modest.

I think it all worked well together.

 

It‚Äôs not possible as of yet to have multiple syncopations within Auxy

There‚Äôs a fair amount of wiggle room if you use a modest swing setting, and then mix in 1/12, 1/16, 1/24 and 1/32 quantisations. Add the Offset to that (for drums and samples, including tonal samples) and you‚Äôre not stuck to one swing feel.

(I wouldn‚Äôt recommend using more than two or three timings at once, unless you‚Äôre going for that sloppy, drunken, broken beat style.)

Read full topic
item.source: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: Shepdoge
item.description:
Ah sh*t, I knew I wasn‚Äôt cool

Yeah, over-syncopation is probably my downfall when writing, so I‚Äôll work on that. Thanks for pointing it out.

Sorry to be a pain, but could you elaborate on what you meant by texturing in your original reply? Not because I want that sweet, sweet, positive feedback in my ear (ok maybe), but it would help to know what I was doing well in your opinion so that I can continue doing it

Edit: Although ducker is a parameter that can be changed within each instrument, It‚Äôs not possible as of yet to have multiple syncopations within Auxy. It would be a great feature to add, however, along with tempo automation, individual note velocities, unorthodox time signatures and unsnapping notes on the grid. iirc, Ableton already has a system in which syncopations can be individualised for each track, which would be very handy indeed.

Read full topic
item.source: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Shepdoge:

I really like funky basslines

But, with swing at 10, imo, you‚Äôve gone straight pass ‚Äòfunky‚Äô and entered ‚Äòjaunty and fun‚Äô territory, losing any ‚Äòcool factor‚Äô.

If you‚Äôre rolling with high levels of syncopation, then it‚Äôs also better to layer it with elements that are less syncopated. If it‚Äôs all highly swung (and all instruments are perfectly in time with each other), it just sounds inauthentic.

And keep in mind that there‚Äôs more to ‚Äòfunky‚Äô than syncopation. Simply loading up on syncopation doesn‚Äôt automatically make something funky. It just makes it bouncy.

Read full topic

item.source: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: Shepdoge
item.description:
Dude I love penguins, thanks for showing me that!

But seriously, that was really nice to listen to. I reckon I‚Äôll check them out some more

btw, I‚Äôve noticed myself that I tend to go overboard with swing and ducker. What can I say? I really like funky basslines and punchy beats. Like, I have an unhealthy addiction to them. I think 3/4 of all my projects including backups comprise of discarded beats n‚Äô bass lines

Also, when you say texturing, do you mean the layering of the notes into their separate octaves within the primary melody, or the layering of the instruments themselves?

Read full topic
item.source: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
me-myself-and-i

Good melodies.

‚Ä¶ (click for more details)

 

Double Deux

Again, like Trey‚Äôs piece, it really commits to melody as the impetus within the track.

I can imagine this working well with a live band, possibly rocked up a bit. Maybe even math rock it up a bit.
The lead melody would make for an interesting rock guitar solo performance piece.

 
I checked out a few of your pieces on SC, and it‚Äôs clear that you engage with lead melodies, though some are more prominent than others.

Read full topic

item.title: Where dem big lead melodies at? Where dem solos?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Gave it a listen. (I actually recall hearing it a while ago.)

Definitely very melody based.

I think what you have could be developed into a good track, but in its current form, it feels like a compositional draft.
Imo, it would benefit from more work on the composition ‚Äì and a lot more work on the sound design.

(I‚Äôd start on the sound design as that may end up steering compositional changes as the ‚Äòfeel‚Äô fleshes out.)

Read full topic
